newsitem.title: USA: Fed cuts back on foreign currency line to Treasury.
newsitem.headline: Fed cuts back on foreign currency line to Treasury.

text.p: The Federal Reserve said it agreed unanimously at a February meeting to reduce the amount of foreign currencies that it is is prepared to "warehouse" for the Treasury to $5 billion from $20 billion.
The amount eligible for warehousing had been increased to $20 billion in early 1995 to facilitate the economic rescue of Mexico. Mexico has since repaid its loans from the U.S.

Warehousing -- which involves a swap of foreign currencies between the central bank and the Treasury -- boosts the foreign exchange resources available to Treasury for intervention in currency markets and for other purposes.

At its Feb 4-5 meeting, the central bank's policymaking Federal Open Market Committee reauthorized the New York Fed bank to carry out foreign exchange intervention if and when needed and reaffirmed a directive governing such operations.

Richmond Fed President Alfred Broaddus dissented from the action because he believed that Fed participation in currency intervention compromises its ability to conduct monetary policy effectively, minutes from the meeting said.
